tanks.note: Assault and landing division - no organic tank units

supply_logistics.supply_status: Critical deterioration. Division arrived Tunisia November 1942 with adequate supplies. By April-May 1943, facing severe shortages of fuel, ammunition, food, and medical supplies due to Allied interdiction of supply lines from Sicily. Axis surrender 13 May 1943 driven partly by complete supply collapse.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Tunisia: mixed terrain - coastal plains, rocky hills, wadis, mountainous regions (Medjerda Valley, Enfidaville position)

subordinate_units.notes: Specialized assault engineers with flame-throwers, demolitions
Medical (3 field hospitals), supply, transport, signals companies

tactical_doctrine.role: Assault and landing division trained for combined operations and amphibious warfare. Specialized in mountain warfare and assault tactics.
special_capabilities: Amphibious assault training (Leghorn combined operations center)
Decentralized heavy weapons for independent battalion operations
known_issues: Never employed in intended amphibious role in North Africa
Severe supply shortages in final Tunisia campaign
Binary division structure (2 regiments vs 3) reduced infantry strength
Limited anti-tank capability against Allied armor
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Division arrived Tunisia late in campaign (November 1942). Limited time for desert acclimatization. Faced steep learning curve in North African conditions compared to veteran Afrika Korps units.

scenario_suitability: Final Axis resistance before surrender 13 May 1943
Allied breakthrough operations against depleted Axis forces
special_rules: Supply Crisis: -1 to all combat rolls representing fuel/ammunition shortages
Assault Training: +1 to close assault actions
Encircled: No retreat options after April 1943 (Tunis pocket)
Inevitable Surrender: Division ceased to exist 13 May 1943
historical_engagements: Final Axis stand before surrender 13 May 1943

1943q2_personnel_strength.reason: Available source data from June 1942 (942ifba.pdf shows ~4,500 personnel for partial units). Division strength extrapolated to 1943-Q2 accounting for reinforcements, attrition, and combat losses during Tunisia campaign.
sources_checked: US G-2 OOB July 1943 (states standard assault division ~12,500 strength)
TM E 30-420 (ordinary infantry division ~12,500 including 1,350 Blackshirts)
1943q2_personnel_strength.estimate_method: Applied 30% attrition to standard assault division strength (12,500) based on: (1) Heavy combat losses November 1942 - May 1943, (2) Supply crisis reducing effective strength, (3) No replacement pipeline in encircled Tunisia. Estimated 8,500 effective personnel at April-May 1943.
1943q2_personnel_strength.mitigation: Cross-reference with Allied intelligence assessments of Italian division strengths in Tunisia April-May 1943 if available

artillery_100mm_presence.reason: June 1942 source lists '3 Battalions (3 btrys 75mm/18 howitzers each bn)' and '1 Battalion (3 btrys 20mm guns)' but standard Italian artillery regiment TO&E typically includes medium howitzer battalion. 100mm/17 presence estimated but not explicitly documented.
artillery_100mm_presence.estimate_method: Standard semi-motorized artillery regiment includes 2x 75/27 gun battalions, 1x 100/17 howitzer battalion. Superga likely similar organization but with 75/18 pack howitzers due to assault/mountain role.
artillery_100mm_presence.mitigation: Seek specific 5th Superga Artillery Regiment TO&E documents or war diary entries
